title: coronavirus qa when travel restrictions lifted how holiday refund
story: When might our travel plans return to normal? Put your questions to our travel expert Nick TrendTransport and industryEver since the Foreign Office announced its blanket warning against all overseas travel, holidaymakers have wondered when their travel plans might return to normal. However, it's not just a case of lifting the UK's restrictions. All but 11 countries, as of April 6, have banned British travellers over coronavirus. And what about those with holidays already booked for later in the year? Should you cancel or wait and see if the situation improves? The Daily 's Chief Consumer and Culture Editor, Nick Trend, will be answering your  travel and holiday questions at 1 p.m. (BST) today. Leave your questions in the comments section at the bottom of this article. Alternatively, if you are reading this on the  app, or don’t have a  account, you can submit a question by emailing yourstory@telegraph. If you would like to remain anonymous, please disclose this when you ask your question. It's our last one for today. Apologies if we haven't answered your question. We've been flooded with queries but there will be lots more travel Q&ampAs in the near future. reader Marian says: Two weeks before the Coronavirus restrictions I booked and paid a substantial down payment on a South America holiday booked with Trailfinders. We are due to fly to Lima on 27th June and we will also visit Brazil.I am due to pay the balance next week on 15th April. Trailfinders have sent me generic emails asking people not to contact them about departures in MayJune  at this stage. The email also said that cancellations after 15th May would be subject to cancellation policy as flights will have resumed.I am reluctant to pay the balance because of the uncertainty and the risk of travelling. Even if travel restrictions are relaxed and flights resume there must still be a substantial risk from the virus. Also I do not know whether my group travel insurance will cover us if we contract the virus.So I am concerned that if I do not pay the balance I will lose the substantial down payment. But if I pay the balance and in June the virus still poses a risk and we decide not to go then I will lose the full price of the holiday, if travel restrictions are lifted and flights resume I will be unable to claim on insurance.And here's Nick's final answer for today: This is a tricky situation. Trialfinders is an extremely reliable company and I would trust what they say. I would contact them three or four days before the rest of the payment is due and discuss your options then.Telegraph reader Shri says: We have booked tickets to Barcelona for Easter holidays through Iberia (British Airways concern). Their customer care executive in clear terms told me that they will refund if there is foreign travel advice against Spain. I tried to contact them after the advisory and they refused to refund, instead offering vouchers, which are not useful for us as it was a one time trip for us to BarcelonaSpain booked and our Visas will also be not valid after 6 monthsNow I can't contact them via phone(they run a automated voucher message and hang up) or email (as there is none provided on their website)How can I get the refunds on these tickets? Here's what Nick has to say:You mention visas, which suggests you are not British citizens and I don’t know where you bought your tickets. If you bought them in the UK, you are legally entitled to a cash refund and you should continue to press for that, though it may take some time and you may feel that accepting a voucher may be a better option. If you bought them or were planning to travel from another country, your rights may be different.A very tricky one here. Katherine Mills says: My 18 year old daughter has booked a weeks holiday to Zante, departing on the 29th June, with 11 of her friends.They have the last instalment to be paid at the end of this month should they pay it?My daughter had travel insurance at the time of booking, some of the group didn’t take travel insurance out until a month or so after booking the holiday. Will they need to claim on their travel insurance to get their money back, if they are unable to go?  If they do, will it make a difference as to when u purchased your travel insurance?From Nick: Tricky - if they don’t pay then they will lose their holiday. Travel insurance will make no difference in that situation. If they pay they can either go on the holiday, or , if it is cancelled, claim a refund. Make sure that the operator has an Atol bond to ensure the booking is financially  secure if it goes out of business in the meantime.An anonymous one here: I am due to fly out from LHR to Havana, Cuba via Madrid on the 25th May 2020, then from Havana to New York on the 3rd June, finally New York to London on the 6th June. British Airways have said that as we are due to fly to Madrid, am I able to receive a credit voucher to use within 12 months of departure. The flight itself, however, hasn’t been cancelled according to Sky Scanner. Am I able to have a refund instead of a credit voucher?  Are airlines able to withdraw the offer of a credit note if the ban is lifted later but before the date of travel?Nick says: You are only entitled to a refund if the flight is cancelled. I suppose in theory the airline could withdraw its offer, but it seems unlikely - BA has been very flexible in allowing changes to flights due to depart before the end of May.This one comes from  John Lavendar who is currently in South Africa. John says: We are presently stranded in South Africa, under a lockdown similar to that in the UK but more rigid. The UK government is talking about 'rescue flights' but I suspect they will be of use only to those already in J'burg or Cape Town. We are hundreds of miles from those places. We are comfortable enough and happy to sit it out until commercial flights are resumed, but our home is in the Isle of Man, which presently has closed its 'borders' with the UK. We are concerned that when, eventually, we can fly from SA that we might get to London with no prospect of going on to the Isle of Man. How do you think that 'transit' airline passengers (albeit 'delayed transit' passengers) will be handled by the UK authorities?Here's what Nick has to say:I’m afraid there are several imponderables in your question which can’t be answered until the situation becomes clearer.I would keep in touch with the authorities on the Isle of Man - they will have a line of communication with the UK government and should be able to give you some guidance when the lockdowns are relaxed.Via email, Kim Hill says: We have been visiting the UK and now wish to drive in our car back to our main residence, which is in Spain. I know France is allowing travel in France to get to a main residence, but what if that main residence is not in France? Are the French authorities allowing travel through and across France to get to the Spanish border?Nick: I assume so, but you should check with the French embassy in London and also remember that whatever the official position is, you may find inidual gendarmes take a different view.Shrddha Shah says: My parents are in India at the moment since January and they are due to return in May they want to come back to London, what do you think they should do? I don’t know where’s safer for them, my Mum has asthma diabetes and high BP I don’t know what advice to give them, I don’t know if they’re safe in Gujarat, Ahmedabad, or better home?Nick: I think your parents should consult a doctor in Gujurat and take advice from him or her. They will be in a much better position to evaluate the risk to your parents’ health.Looking ahead, Claire Templeton says: When do you think it likely that airlines will announce flight cancellations for May? And when will government advice on travel be extended to May? Many are frustrated as they know they won’t be able to travel but can’t get a refund of Air bnb accommodation as policies don’t allow for ‘travel advisories’ and require evidence that overlaps with travel dates.The Foreign Office has just extended its advice against all but essential travel overseas indefinitely, but may rescind it at any time after April 15. I imagine most airlines will be taking a decision about May in the next couple of weeks. BA and Ryanair have both said or implied that it is unlikely they will operate much of a service before June.Andrew Linelll says: I have just returned a week early from a holiday in St Lucia. I have been unable to identify any government advice for travellers returning to the UK. Should we (a) self- isolate and if so, for how long? Or (b) simply follow social-distancing and work from home advice?Nick: There is no specific advice for travellers returning to the UK  without symptoms, so you should remain at home and stick to the current government guidelines on social distancing.One more via email. An anonymous reader says: How about people who’ve finally managed to get flights back into the country. How do they travel from the airport in London to say their home in Manchester? Can they use public transport?Here's what Nick has to say: Yes. Foreign Office advice is for all British citizens to return to the UK, so obviously they need to return home once they arrive back at the airport. Although much more limited than usual, trains, tubes and some domestic flights are still operating, so someone would be able to travel back from a London airport to Manchester by public transport.Another question here via email.  reader David Norris asks: My wife lives in south-west France, can I drive there to see her?Nick: As I understand it, you would have a hard time justifying this unless she were ill or in need of care. It would be against FCO guidelines to leave the country and against government rules on driving within the UK. You also might face questions en-route by the French police. Eurotunnel, which is offering a limited service is defining travel to France as essential only for those whose main residence is in France or who have to work there.Our next question comes from Kim Hill via email. Kim asks:We have been visiting the UK and now wish to drive in our car back to our main residence, which is in Spain. I know France is allowing travel in France to get to a main residence, but what if that main residence is not in France? Are the French authorities allowing travel through and across France to get to the Spanish border?Here's what Nick has to say:I assume so, but you should check with the French embassy in London and also remember that whatever the official position is, you may find inidual gendarmes take a different view. My son-in-law has booked a ten day holiday through Sykes Holiday Cottages over Easter for four adults and two children in Tomintoul, Scotland.  My wife and myself are part of the party and as we fall into the vulnerable age group we are concerned about making this journey. My daughter is also an essential worker during this crisis.  Our plan, therefore, is to cancel the holiday but Sykes Holiday Cottages say it is a non-cancellation booking. My son in law paid via debit card. Is there any way we can reclaim this cost?Here's what Nick has to say:I’m confused about this because you are not allowed to travel over Easter. And Sykes should already have cancelled the booking and be offering a refund or a postponement. I would get your son-in-law to check the website or contact Sykes as a matter of urgency.Our next question comes from Alex Woolley via email. Alex asks: We are due to travel to northern Italy on June 27 on a holiday of a life time all by rail, through Great Rail Journeys. We have paid £1200 deposit. The balance is due on the April 24. (Approx £7k). Should we be paying the balance in light of the current situation? Any advice would be greatly appreciated.This is a tricky situation which many people are facing (see my answer to the previous question). If you would feel happier postponing the trip, then I would definitely talk to GRJ and see if you can rebook for next year. If you can’t then wait and see what the situation is looking like in a week or ten days time - things may seem more certain by then.My holiday booked with Emirates Holidays has been cancelled due to coronavirus. As I explained to Emirates Holidays I am self-employed with no idea when I will next be in a job and unlikely to find out anytime soon. I contacted the service desk for a refund and (after over 70 frustrating minutes on hold) I was told to contact my travel insurance. Claiming on my insurance, if the claim is approved, will cost me policy excess charges and increase my premiums not to mention considerable inconvenience and further delay. This is disgraceful service from a supposedly ABTA AND ATOL agent. While I understand the situation is unprecedented, it is also unprecedented for the customers and their families who may also now be facing considerable financial hardship and stress. I am also unsure how to get refunds for the hundreds of pounds paid directly to the airline for reserved seating and upgrades. Is there anything I can do? Would be great if the government could offer stronger advice on this as thousands of families are impacted.Nick has the following advice:Your situation is a familiar one I’m afraid. You are entitled to a refund and I think you will get one eventually, but there is not much you can do until some of the pressure has eased on travel companies. Frankly, if you insurance does cover the cancellation then claiming on that may be the easiest and quickest way of getting most of your money back.I was due to move to Spain three weeks ago. I have an official tenancy agreement and had given up my accommodation in Hove. Everything is packed and ready to go. I have been in isolation for the last three weeks and have followed the government advice. I looked on the gov.org website last night to find that I can actually travel if i'm trying to get home, which is the case. I also looked at getting a ferry from Newhaven to Dieppe and they are still running. I am travelling alone and am obviously driving there. The borders are open for people travelling home and I can prove this. I am happy to travel at this time as the roads will be clear and it should be an easy run. My only concern is that I will have to break the journey up into at least three parts requiring me to spend the night somewhere twice. There are hotels open for people en-route and key workers. My question is, am I within my rights to do this?Here's what Nick has to say:You are probably technically within your rights, but you may find is difficult to organise your hotel stays, and if you are stopped en route, different police forces or even different policeman may take a different view. It’s one of those very difficult situations with no easy answers I’m afraid. If you can possibly postpone it may be the best course of action.I have just returned a week early from a holiday in St Lucia. I have been unable to identify any government advice for travellers returning to the UK. Should we (a) self- isolate and if so, for how long? Or (b) simply follow social-distancing and work from home advice?Here's what Nick has to say:There is no specific advice for travellers returning to the UK  without symptoms, so you should remain at home and stick to the current government guidelines on social distancing.Our next question comes from a reader who'd like to remain anonymous. They ask:I have a question about UK holidays booked through Hoseseasons as an agent.Our cottage holiday has been cancelled (not confirmed by Hoseseasons yet) confirmed by the company closing their establishment.I do feel sympathetic towards the holiday provider but my question is can Hoseseasons refuse a refund and only offer alternative dates or can I push for a refund as they have not provided the service I paid for on the specific dates I paid for that service?Here's what Nick has to say:Legally speaking, it seems clear cut that you are the victim of a cancellation and should be entitled to a cash refund rather than a credit or a postponement. I haven’t spoken to Hoseasons directly, but many companies - facing an extremely difficult financial situation - are doing their best to avoid paying out cash. They argue that these are extreme circumstances and that the cancellations are not their fault. Keep trying for a refund if it’s important to you, but you may face a long battle.Our next question also comes via email and is from John Booth. John asks: We are booked for a big family holiday to Orlando in July with Virgin Holidays.The balance is due in a couple of weeks and we are wondering what to do. My wife and I are self isolating at present. Would it be possible to see if Virgin would carry the deposit over until next year ?We don’t want to pay the balance and risk losing a lot of money as the party is  six adults and five children.Nick has the following advice:This is a tricky situation which many people are facing. I would definitely talk to Virgin and see if you can rebook for next year. If you can’t then wait and see what the situation is looking like in a week or ten days time - things may seem more certain by then.I have a holiday to Cyprus booked for then middle of August. Will I be able to travel?Here's what Nick has to say:It’s obviously impossible to say for sure, but there is a good chance you will be able to travel, assuming the virus is under control both here and in Cyprus. Certainly you shouldn’t think about cancelling until much near the time, or you risk losing the money you have already paid for your holiday.We have a holiday booked with TUI for travel to Tenerife on April 21. It is patently obvious that we won’t be able to travel but for the moment are unable to cancel. Why is this?Nick has the following to say:This is because, until this weekend the Foreign Office had only advised against travel overseas until April 15. Operators weren’t cancelling holidays beyond that because there was no legal requirement to do so, but also because they are currently struggling to cope with cancelling so many holidays due to depart before that date. The FCO has now extended its advice indefinitely however and I’m sure that TUI will focus on cancellations beyond April 21 very soon.Our first question comes from Kara Betton via email. Kara asks:When will we know if the Foreign Travel (non essential travel ban) is extended? When will we be able to start travelling abroad again?We are currently forbidden to travel abroad until mid-April as stated by the foreign travel advice. Many people have had holidays cancelled throughout the March and April period. However, Jet2 are planning to recommence travel abroad from May 1 depending upon the advice given.Here's what Nick has to say:In fact, the Foreign Office extended the ban indefinitely over the weekend, so that it is advising against all but essential travel in future, with no end date. This is an extremely confusing situation. Clearly, the FCO will, at some point lift its advisory for some destinations at least. And it can change the advice at any time.  But it is not clear how much notice it will give, nor how tour operators and travellers should deal with plans which have already been made in, say May, June or July. Instead of have a clear date - even one which may shift in stages - the FCO has left us in no man’s land. Personally, I think Jet2 are overly optimistic. Ryanair says that it is not expecting to significantly increase its flying programme until June.This Q&ampA will be starting in ten minutes. Leave your questions for Nick in the comments section below or email them to yourstory@telegraph. See you soon!Transport and industryThe  values your comments but kindly requests all posts are on topic, constructive and respectful. title: follow bards footsteps unleash wave national creativity kitchen
story: Shakespeare, our greatest writer, certainly knew how to make the most of his self-isolationIt’s the summer of 1606. London faces another outbreak of the plague, and your housekeeper Marie Mountjoy has fallen sick. The playhouses have been closed, so you spend your time scribbling down ideas for a new play: King Lear.Shakespeare, our greatest writer, certainly knew how to make the most of his self-isolation. With people stuck at home due to Coronavirus, we have set up the King Lear Prizes to encourage ordinary people to write, compose and create while they are in quarantine. The prizes are specifically for people with no professional experience in the arts and who have never been published before.   You’ve seen those Italians showing off and singing opera on the balconies of their apartment buildings whilst in quarantine. Well Britain’s answer will be perhaps a little more understated, but no less creative: an army of new indoor poets, authors, composers, dramatists and artists!  Our initial prizes are for people over 70 who are subject to the strictest quarantine conditions. They will need to add pencils and writing paper to their shopping lists for their volunteer helpers. However, given the pleas of parents who are working at home with their children, I suspect we will soon need to launch new prizes to keep the children busy too.  There are five categories: short story, short drama, poetry, musical composition, and art and you’ve got eight weeks to plan, write and refine your entries. If you have a creation inside you, get it out. Get it on paper and get it to us.  It would be easy to think of the arts as for solitary souls only: writers, composers and artists working away in their studios or studies without talking to anyone else, like creative hermits. But that couldn’t be further from the point of this competition! The arts are social, and the best part of this competition will be showing off your own entry to your friends and family.  We have panels of eminent judges like Julian Lloyd Webber and Steven Knight who have generously offered their time to select the winners, and we are offering a £1,000 prize for the top winner in each section. We’ll be sharing the short-listed entries with the public online, and we’ve got fantastic arts organisations like the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra ready to perform the winning works.  So if you are at home and are up for a creative challenge, it’s time to sharpen your pencil and start writing. If your parents or grandparents are at home, and could do with a challenge, call them up and tell them about the King Lear Prizes. Now is the time for a new wave of British artistic creativity to be unleashed, straight from the kitchen table.The  values your comments but kindly requests all posts are on topic, constructive and respectful. Debenhams said it was preparing for all of its stores to reopen once the coronavirus lockdown conditions are eased by the government.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe company said in a statement: “This move will protect Debenhams from the threat of legal action that could have the effect of pushing the business into liquidation while its 142 UK stores remain closed in line with the government’s current advice regarding the covid-19 pandemic.”It came as&nbspdata showed the increasingly heavy economic toll caused by coronavirus, with construction slumping to its worst performance since the financial crisis, new car registrations plunging by more than 40 per cent and consumer confidence dropping at its fastest pace in more than four decades.When can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?Listen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastSome 203,000 fewer new cars were registered in March than during the same month in 2019, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders. A separate report from Auto Analysis and Global Data forecast that manufacturers will lose out on $100bn (£82bn) in car sales as their factories lie dormant across Europe and North America.Meanwhile, the UK construction sector suffered its largest job cuts since 2010 after measures to stop the spread of coronavirus halted work and caused a slump in new orders.The closely watched IHS MarkitChartered Institute of Procurement and&nbspSupply (CIPS)&nbspconstruction purchasing managers’ index&nbspdropped to 39.3 for March, from 52.6 in February. Analysts had forecast a reading of 44, with anything below 50 indicating a contraction in activity.Duncan Brock, the group director at the CIPS, said: “With no upturn in sight, and with the fastest level of lay-offs since September 2010, the sector is stuck in quicksand and sinking further.”There was more bad news for retailers too after a survey showed that consumer confidence plummeted in the last two weeks of March – a period in which some 950,000 people made new benefit claims.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Cash remains king at present and those businesses without cash or access to credit lines will have massive problems.”Stefaan Vansteenkiste, the chief executive of Debenhams, said on Monday: “These are unprecedented circumstances and we have taken this step to protect our business, our employees&nbspand other important stakeholders so that we are in a position to resume trading from our stores when government restrictions are lifted.“We are working with a group of highly supportive owners and lenders and anticipate that additional funding will be made available to bridge us through the current crisis period.“With their support and working with other key stakeholders, including landlords, pension trustees and business partners, we are striving to protect jobs and reopen as many Debenhams stores for trading as we can, as soon as this is possible.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Struggling department store chain exploring options as 140 stores remain closed during Covid-19 outbreakStruggling department store chain Debenhams may put administrators on standby as soon as next week, according to a report.Debenhams, which employs 22,000 people, went through a restructuring process known as a pre-pack less than a year ago which saw shareholders, including Sports Direct founder Mike Ashley, wiped out.The 242-year old company is in the process of closing around 50 stores as it seeks to slash costs and focus on profitable sites. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘These are unprecedented circumstances,’ says chief executive of department store chainDebenhams announced it will file for administration as figures showed the extent to which Britain’s economy is suffering during the coronavirus pandemic.The struggling department store chain, which employs 22,000 people, will bring in administrators to try to protect itself from legal action that could bring about the company’s collapse.Debenhams faced being chased by suppliers and other creditors who have not been paid as a result of the coronavirus pandemic. Debenhams said it was preparing for all of its stores to reopen once the coronavirus lockdown conditions are eased by the government.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe company said in a statement: “This move will protect Debenhams from the threat of legal action that could have the effect of pushing the business into liquidation while its 142 UK stores remain closed in line with the government’s current advice regarding the covid-19 pandemic.”It came as&nbspdata showed the increasingly heavy economic toll caused by coronavirus, with construction slumping to its worst performance since the financial crisis, new car registrations plunging by more than 40 per cent and consumer confidence dropping at its fastest pace in more than four decades.When can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?Listen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastSome 203,000 fewer new cars were registered in March than during the same month in 2019, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders. A separate report from Auto Analysis and Global Data forecast that manufacturers will lose out on $100bn (£82bn) in car sales as their factories lie dormant across Europe and North America.Meanwhile, the UK construction sector suffered its largest job cuts since 2010 after measures to stop the spread of coronavirus halted work and caused a slump in new orders.The closely watched IHS MarkitChartered Institute of Procurement and&nbspSupply (CIPS)&nbspconstruction purchasing managers’ index&nbspdropped to 39.3 for March, from 52.6 in February. Analysts had forecast a reading of 44, with anything below 50 indicating a contraction in activity.Duncan Brock, the group director at the CIPS, said: “With no upturn in sight, and with the fastest level of lay-offs since September 2010, the sector is stuck in quicksand and sinking further.”There was more bad news for retailers too after a survey showed that consumer confidence plummeted in the last two weeks of March – a period in which some 950,000 people made new benefit claims.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Flybe said it cancelled 994 flights in the three months to 31 March, compared to 372 in the same period last year.People were asked about changes to their personal finances, the general economy and whether they feel now is the right time to make major purchases, during interviews between 16 and 27 March.The results produced an overall negative score in the “consumer confidence barometer” from GfK of minus 34, indicating a sharp decline in confidence of 25 points from a score of minus nine in mid-March.Debenhams had been in trouble before the current crisis, which has seen all but essential shops close their doors. A year ago, the chain went through a restructuring process known as a pre-pack administration, which saw lenders take control&nbspand shareholders, including Mike Ashley’s Sports Direct, wiped out.The 242-year-old company is already in the process of closing around 50 stores as it seeks to slash costs and focus on profitable sites. Of those, 22 have shut so far.Debenhams said the new administration would be “light touch”, suggesting it would not involve further, large-scale store closures but some analysts remain sceptical.“This is the first example of a so-called ‘light touch’ administration which has been promoted by practitioners to protect the company from hostile actions during the current crisis,” said David Ereira, a restructuring partner and insolvency expert at international law firm Paul Hastings. “Debenhams has, however, been in financial difficulty for some time now, so how long any new measures can keep it afloat remain to be seen.”Sean Moran, an insolvency partner at law firm Shakespeare Martineau&nbspwarned that other well-known names may be forced to call in the administrators.“The government has stated its intention to facilitate cash injections and other financial assistance to businesses, recognising the imminent threat of insolvencies in many sectors,” he said. “These measures include the temporary business rates relief set out in the Budget which will benefit many smaller retailers in the short term.“It remains to be seen how quickly the processes for accessing other funds and the payment mechanisms promised will actually materialise. Cash remains king at present and those businesses without cash or access to credit lines will have massive problems.”Stefaan Vansteenkiste, the chief executive of Debenhams, said on Monday: “These are unprecedented circumstances and we have taken this step to protect our business, our employees&nbspand other important stakeholders so that we are in a position to resume trading from our stores when government restrictions are lifted.“We are working with a group of highly supportive owners and lenders and anticipate that additional funding will be made available to bridge us through the current crisis period.“With their support and working with other key stakeholders, including landlords, pension trustees and business partners, we are striving to protect jobs and reopen as many Debenhams stores for trading as we can, as soon as this is possible.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - However, she said such restrictions should only be imposed in the right conditions.“The message we are getting is if we don’t take care of nature, it will take care of us,” Ms&nbspMrema&nbsptold&nbsp.When can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?Listen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus Podcast“It would be good to ban the live animal markets as China has done and some countries. But we should also remember you have communities, particularly from low-income rural areas, particularly in Africa, which are dependent on wild animals to sustain the livelihoods of millions of people,” she said.“Unless we get alternatives for these communities, there might be a danger of opening up illegal trade in wild animals which currently is already leading us to the brink of extinction for some species.”China temporarily banned people&nbspfrom eating and trading wildlife&nbspfor food earlier this year&nbspas the country&nbspworked to combat the spread of coronavirus.​Humane Society International, an animal charity, has&nbspcalled for this ban to become a permanent fixture across the globe.“The capture and consumption of wild animals is a global trade that causes immense suffering for hundreds of thousands of animals every year, including endangered wildlife species being traded to the brink of extinction,” said president Jeffrey Flocken.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus viral load genetics young people genes symptoms covid 19
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Scientists are racing to build database of DNA research to find any genetic reasons people may be more or less susceptible to deadly virusThe coronavirus pandemic has hit older people far harder than those who are younger, but scientists are yet to fully understand why this is.Many of the elderly people who have died have had pre-existing health conditions such as heart disease, lung disease and diabetes, all of which make fighting the virus more difficult, but many have not had any such health problems, and occasionally the virus has caused the deaths of younger, apparently healthy people.Researchers around the world are racing to learn how the virus behaves, which health factors put people most at risk, and are trying to work out whether there may be genetic traits that could mean some people respond to the infection differently to others.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThere are various theories to suggest why the virus is so unusually — and devastatingly — selective.&nbspSome scientists have suggested the greater the amount of virus that infects an inidual — known as the “viral load” — could make a large difference to how the body is able to respond to infection.&nbspWhen can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?Listen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastPut simply,&nbspthe larger the dose of the virus a person gets, the worse the infection is, and the least promising the outcome.&nbspA parallel school of thought is that genetic variations between humans — differences in our DNA — could affect how susceptible an inidual is to the virus.&nbspAnd another candidate for why apparently healthy young people are dying is they may have a highly reactive immune system, which is sent into overdrive fighting off the virus. In such a scenario, a huge inflammation storm could inadvertently overwhelm vital organs such as the lungs.None of the theories compete with one another, and aspects of all of them, as well as innumerable other factors, could be at play in an inidual case.&nbspNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailDr Edward Parker of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, explained how a high viral load can impact humans. He said: “After we are infected with a virus, it replicates in our body’s cells. The total amount of virus a person has inside them is referred to as their ‘viral load’. For Covid-19, early reports from China suggest the viral load is higher in patients with more severe disease, which is also the case for Sars and influenza.&nbsp“The amount of virus we are exposed to at the start of an infection is referred to as the ‘infectious dose’. For influenza, we know that that initial exposure to more virus — or a higher infectious dose — appears to increase the chance of infection and illness. Studies in mice have also shown that repeated exposure to low doses may be just as infectious as a single high dose.”He added: “So all in all, it is crucial for us to limit all possible exposures to Covid-19, whether these are to highly symptomatic iniduals coughing up large quantities of virus or to asymptomatic iniduals shedding small quantities. And if we are feeling unwell, we need to observe strict self-isolation measures to limit our chance of infecting others.”Professor Wendy Barclay, the head of the Department of Infectious Disease at Imperial College London, said existing knowledge of viral load means healthcare workers can be at greater risk of infection.“In general with respiratory viruses, the outcome of infection — whether you get severely ill or only get a mild cold — can sometimes be determined by how much virus actually got into your body and started the infection off.&nbsp It’s all about the size of the armies on each side of the battle, a very large virus army is difficult for our immune systems army to fight off.“So standing further away from someone when they breathe or cough out virus likely means fewer virus particles reach you and then you get infected with a lower dose and get less ill.&nbsp Doctors who have to get very close to patients to take samples from them or to intubate them are at higher risk so need to wear masks.”Genetic differences between those infectedScientists are currently preparing to scour Covid-19 patients’ genomes for DNA variations that might indicate why some people are more at risk than others.&nbspThe findings could then be used to identify groups most at risk of serious illness and those who might be protected, and this knowledge could then inform the hunt for effective treatments.&nbspA huge effort to pool DNA research from patients around the world is now on, with the ultimate goal being to build a body of evidence from people with no underlying health issues, but who have reacted differently to infection by the virus.One promising strand of research into why some people are more susceptible to the coronavirus is on the gene variation for the cell surface protein angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), found on the outer membranes of cells, and which the coronavirus uses to enter cells in the lungs and airways.Variations in production of ACE2 could make it easier or more difficult for the virus to enter and infect cells.“We see huge differences in clinical outcomes and across countries. How much of that is explained by genetic susceptibility is a very open question,” geneticist Andrea Ganna, of the University of Helsinki’s Institute for Molecular Medicine Finland, told Science Magazine.&nbspAnother fascinating line of inquiry is whether different blood types could lead to differing levels of susceptibility to the disease.A Chinese research team reported in a non-peer-reviewed article that people with type O blood may be protected from the virus, and those with type A blood could be at greater risk.&nbsp“We’re trying to figure out if those findings are robust,” Stanford University human geneticist Manuel Rivas told Science Magazine.The first results from the investigations into genetic differences and susceptibility are expected in less than two months’ time.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - Mice inhaled the virus in one single dose.When those same&nbspmice were exposed to a usually lethal dose of MERS, four weeks later, all of them survived. All of the mice that were given the vaccine died.When can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?Listen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastScientists now hope they can use the largely harmless virus – known as&nbspparainfluenza virus 5 or PIV5 – to deliver vaccines for other coronavirus diseases.Our new study indicates that PIV5 may be a useful vaccine platform for emerging coronavirus diseases, including SARS-CoV-2, the virus causing the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, said Paul McCray, a professor at the UI Carver College of Medicine and one of the authors of the study.Using the same strategy, vaccine candidates based on PIV5 expressing the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 have been generated. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Clear skies and less air pollution mean&nbspApril&nbspcould be the best time&nbspto witness the celestial event in 2020The biggest and brightest full moon of the year will rise over the skies of the UK this week, offering the best chance to view a supermoon in 2020.Tuesday’s supermoon&nbsp–&nbspofficially referred to as a perigean full moon – will be the third month in a row&nbspfor the rare celestial event. It occurs when the full moon is at its closest point to Earth in its monthly orbit.On 7-8 April, the moon will get as close as 356,907km (221,772&nbspmiles) to Earth, making it appear bigger and brighter in the night's sky.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe time of year means this full moon is known in folklore as the 'Pink moon', as it usually coincides with spring flower blossoms.The best time and date to see April's&nbspsupermoon&nbspis at moonrise on Tuesday and at moonset on Wednesday, when it is close to the horizon.How to take the perfect picture of the supermoon this weekThis is due to an optical illusion that makes it appear even bigger due to its relative size to buildings and objects on the horizon.&nbspThe supermoon's peak illumination will take place just after&nbsp6pm&nbspGMT on Tuesday, though it may not be visible until after sunset.The term was first coined by astrologer Richard Nolle&nbspin 1979, who defined a supermoon&nbspas any full moon that was within 90 per cent of its closest approach.The coinage and use of the term has been criticised by astronomers, however some welcome it as a way to encourage interest&nbspin astronomy.“Some astronomers complain about the name supermoon. They like to call supermoons hype,” astronomer and EarthSky contributor Bruce McClure wrote recently.Created with Sketch.9 best images of the 2016 supermoon Show all 9Created with Sketch.Created with with getting a perfect picture of the supermoon if you have time to plan it. You can look up the best monuments or statues in your area to photograph the image of the moon against, like Mr Ingalls does in Washington D.C., where he lives. “It means doing a lot of homework. I use Google Maps and other apps – even a compass – to plan where to get just the right angle at the right time,” he told Nasa.Get the right exposureIf you’re taking a picture on your camera, control the light balance by first tapping the screen where the moon appears to get the camera to focus on the object before dragging your finger up and down to play with the exposure. “You’ll usually want to drag it down for underexposure to be sure you have all the highlight detail,” National Geographic photographer Michael Christopher Brown said.Use a tripod for your camera or rest your phone on a solid surfaceDavid Reneke, an astronomer and writer for Australian science magazine told ABC.net that if you’re using an SLR or DSLR then it’s important to play with aperture settings on your camera to photograph the supermoon, but that using a tripod is essential.It’s worth using a tripod for taking pictures with a smartphone too, as any camera shake can compromise the quality of the pictures – but if you don’t have one to hand you can simply rest your phone on a window ledge.For older smartphones that use a digital zoom rather than an optical zoom, it’s generally best not to use the zoom as it could compromise the quality of the image. Instead, take the picture and then crop it.Newer phones like the Huawei P30 and P40 series feature incredible zoom capabilities that can take detailed pictures of far away objects. title: coronavirus catherine calderwood scotland chief medical officer second home
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘I understand that I did not follow the advice I am giving to others, and I am truly sorry for that,’ says Catherine CalderwoodScotland’s chief medical officer has apologised for breaking coronavirus lockdown measures to visit her second home in Fife, which first minister Nicola Sturgeon has said she was “wrong” to do.Dr Catherine Calderwood&nbspapologised “unreservedly” and said she would continue to focus on her job in a statement. She added her reasons for visiting her second home were “not legitimate reasons to be out of my home” and understood she did not follow her own advice.“While I and my family followed the guidance on social distancing at all times, I understand that I did not follow the advice I am giving to others, and I am truly sorry for that.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“I know how important this advice is and I do not want my mistake to distract from that,” added Dr Calderwood.“I have a job to do as chief medical officer to provide advice to ministers on the path of this virus and to support the medical profession as they work night and day to save lives, and having spoken with the first minister this morning I will continue to focus entirely on that job.”When can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?Listen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastThe apology&nbspcomes after The Scottish Sun published photos of Dr Calderwood and her family near a coastal retreat in Earlsferry, more than an hour away from Edinburgh,&nbsplate on Saturday.Days before, the 51-year-old posted a photo of her family at their main residence in Edinburgh on Twitter, as they joined the rest of the nation in clapping for front line NHS workers.In the daily coronavirus press briefing on Sunday, Ms Sturgeon&nbspsaid: “The chief medical officer made a mistake in travelling away from her home. Whatever her reasons for doing so, it was wrong and she knows that.“All of us, including me, will make mistakes in these unprecedented times we are living in. When we do we must be candid about it and learn from it.”She said Dr Calderwood is learning from her error and has offered to do whatever is in the interests of the country, adding: “In my view, that would not be her resignation.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. It is vital that everyone adhere&nbspto these requirements.“Police officers and staff are putting themselves in harm’s way day and night to explain these instructions to our communities, encourage co-operation and, where necessary, enforce them.”In a joint statement, Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie and Wendy Chamberlain, the MSP and MP respectively for the area where Dr Calderwood has her second home, said: “It is difficult to see how the chief medical officer will be able to carry the important messages about the virus and the lockdown if she has not even followed it herself.”They added: “If we are going to get through this pandemic we need medical leaders who everyone can follow. It is with great regret that we say that the chief medical officer will need to go.”Scotland’s constitution secretary Mike Russell said there was no doubt Dr Calderwood’s visit was “ill-advised”. The&nbspScottish Government confirmed it was an overnight stay to “check on a family home”.Mr Russell said she would be “answerable” for her decision when she appears at the daily coronavirus briefing with Nicola Sturgeon later today.He added: “I’m saying to everybody... do not go out except in the very exceptional circumstances that are listed, think about these things and remember by breaking them you are risking lives.”Scottish Police Federation general secretary Calum Steele said policing the pandemic had been made more difficult and stressed checking on a second home is not one of the “reasonable excuses” providing an exception to emergency coronavirus legislation.He tweeted: “In defending the indefensible has the Scottish Government not just thrown the CMO under the bus? Checking on a 2nd home is not one of the prescribed reasonable excuses.”Monica Lennon,&nbspMSP for central Scotland, said in a statement on Facebook: “As the chief medical officer for Scotland, Catherine Calderwood beams that message into our homes on behalf of the government every single day, however, she has failed to practice what she preaches. Not only is this hypocritical, it is irresponsible and the first minister cannot accept this conduct.“Hundreds of Scots have died and there is no sign of the spread of the virus slowing. title: coronavirus food bank trussell trust support donation food ideas
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Reaching out, at every level, is fundamental to what food banks do, writes Vincent WoodThe government has been forced to step in at an unprecedented scale during the Covid-19 coronavirus pandemic, resolving glaring issues as people across the country are forced to stay at home.&nbspBut those groups who have always been in need in our communities remain just that – in need. People who previously struggled with universal credit continue to do so. Rough sleepers and sofa surfers continue to live without shelter. Services that once offered support have shuttered to protect workers, while people are burning through their kitchen cupboards faster than usual because they are stuck inside.&nbspIn short, many of those who have needed to use food banks in the past, those who are not among the government’s 1.5 million most at-risk people and will not be able to call on its swelling volunteer service for support, still need help.&nbspThe Independent’s Help The Hungry campaign aims to help give these people the support they need. Click here for ways you can help.And here are five things you might not have considered to help you to support your community’s food bank.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesA common misconception is that food banks exist to offer the bare minimum – but to do so would be to completely undermine what food can give us in our day to day lives. We don’t only eat for sustenance – we do it for pleasure, to access our cultures, to engage in tradition. Food is central to the human experience, and for millennia has been key to how we experience love and affection.How to support our campaignSo ultimately think about what is going to taste good. Of course you can pick up staples that will be warmly received, but you can also donate things that get you excited, and share that excitement with someone else.Take, for example, Easter eggs. They may not be a matter of life or death, but by donating them you can give a parent the chance to treat their child, and a child the ability to engage in a communal tradition they might have been left out of. You are not just handing out subsistence, but a moment of dignity and joy for a family – and all it took was a bit of chocolate.It’s not just foodFood banks have never been just about food. Poverty is about choices – do you buy something to eat, or put money on the meter to keep the electricity running? Do you really need the heating on, or can you hold out? Will you be hungry now, or hungry later?&nbspAt their most fundamental level, food banks are about a community pulling together and trying to resolve those conflicts – so when you think of donating, empathy is key. On one side of the spectrum, this means not just dredging mystery tins from the back of your cupboard – if you didn’t want to eat it over the last two years, chances are no one else will either. On the other, it’s about thinking of the groceries you couldn’t live without – be that food or something else.In the early days of the UK epidemic, among the first things to be stockpiled were hygiene products – sanitary towels, hand wash, toilet roll. If you didn’t have the ability to bulk buy, or the spare funds to travel from shop to shop by car or public transport, you were stuck. Donating bathroom products means people who use the service don’t have to choose between hunger and hygiene.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailThe range of reasons people visit food banks is vast, reflecting many of the social issues seen across the country, from universal credit delays to limited post-prison rehabilitation systems, rising rents and jobs that simply do not pay enough to allow for survival.&nbspBut helping rough sleepers and sofa surfers out represents a unique challenge for food banks – particularly those who do not have access to kitchens and so are less likely to feel the benefit of, say, the bag of dry pasta many would receive. While volunteers will build a parcel that helps as much as possible, you can go a step further by putting together boxes of much-needed items that can be handed straight over as is.&nbspAsk if your local service is interested, then get a few shoeboxes and add things that might prove useful – like socks and underwear, first aid kits, compact waterproofs, or toothbrushes and paste. Once again as much as you are donating a small box of odds and ends, you are also handing over dignity, and the tools people need to look after themselves.&nbspBags of bagsFood banks across the country have had to make drastic changes to how they operate due to the virus – while volunteers may have a few contingency plans up their sleeves to keep services running, readying for a global pandemic was not among them.What has followed has been a herculean effort to organise outright change in a matter of days. Entire delivery systems have been dreamt up out of thin air, while the elderly and at risk who make up much of the volunteer base have been sent home.&nbspFood banks strained as volunteers isolate and demand surgesFood banks have never been more needed, or closer to collapseFood banks in crisis as coronvirus panic buying leaves families hungryFood banks are under threat – the government has to step inUnited and City make joint food bank donation to fight coronavirusOperations have also been streamlined to feed as many people as possible, as hygienically as can be achieved. And as every service user’s food is bagged up and handed over, a small mountain of plastic bags are being deployed.So, bizarrely enough, in this time of national crisis, that bag of shopping bags that you and every other UK resident has been keeping in the corner of their kitchen or under their sink for years might finally serve a purpose. After all that time of being stored and neglected after trips to the supermarket, they could be put to use in ensuring social distancing.&nbspAsk your local food bank if they could use them – but if you can go a step further and also feel a little apprehensive about contributing to the impact of plastic on the planet, consider handing over canvas bags instead. There are so many feelings wrapped into asking for help – and when you’ve been let down by the world around you time and time again, one that’s likely to come up is shame.&nbspVolunteers work hard to try to mitigate that – and make the experience about support and community, but it’s easy to feel self-conscious walking away from a food bank and onto the high street with an array of clearly worn and mismatched carrier bags in your hands. A canvas bag, while sturdier, is also more discreet.Possibly the most useful thing you can do for your local food bank is among the easiest – ask what they need. While the Trussell Trust, the nation’s largest food bank charity, helps to set up and support sites, the inidual operation in your region sets its own rules and runs its own show. Others run via other charities or completely independently.&nbspSo check out their tweets to see what they are appealing for, or send them an email to check what they are after, or give them a call and offer up a few hours a week to stack some tins (particularly if you are young, physically fit and don’t mind lugging around crates of produce).&nbspReaching out, at every level, is fundamental to what food banks are. In reaching out you will get the satisfaction that comes from rallying around your community at a time where we’ve perhaps never been more isolated. What the person who comes to ask for food will get, from your contribution combined with others in your area coming together, is help when it’s possible no one else can.Help the hungry&nbsp|&nbspShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: coronavirus help the hungry volunteers london food charity felix project
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘I had some extra time, and I really wanted to do something useful with it,’ says 30-year-old marketing executive now helping pack&nbspparcels&nbspgoing out to vulnerable peopleHundreds of tons&nbspof surplus food have&nbspbeen delivered to people in desperate need since the coronavirus lockdown began two weeks ago – thanks to volunteers stepping up to make sure a mammoth redistribution drive succeeds.The Independent’s&nbspHelp The Hungry&nbspcampaign supports the work going on across the UK to ensure everyone has enough to eat during the current crisis, backed by figures such as London mayor Sadiq Khan, Labour MP Jess Phillips and TV cook Nigella Lawson.Many food aid charities have been struggling with a drop in donations and a fall in the number of regular volunteers due to illness or the need to self-isolate. Yet members of the public still able to help are signing up to serve a worthy cause.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMarina Nenadic, 30, is one of a several new recruits at&nbspCity Harvest&nbspin Acton, west London, after the food surplus charity called for more hands to sort through the produce rescued from restaurants, manufacturers and supermarket packing houses.“I’m working from home four days a week, so I had some extra time, and I really wanted to do something useful with it,” she explained. “It’s within walking distance of where I live, so I’m not taking any extra risks with journeys.”How to support our campaignMs&nbspNenadic&nbspis a marketing executive for&nbspKew&nbspGardens, but she now spends at least one day a week creating crates of food packages for the 300 smaller groups – including&nbspfood banks, low-income family projects and homeless shelters – served by City Harvest.“It’s a really positive atmosphere, despite the fact it’s such difficult times. It’s actually quite exciting to see so much food come in, knowing it’s going out to people who need it. It’s been such a rewarding thing to do.”In the first two weeks of the coronavirus lockdown, City Harvest has rescued and redistributed over 130 tons of surplus food. Responding to the enormous scale of the crisis, the group has joined forces with even larger food surplus charities in the capital – our campaign partner The Felix Project and Fareshare – to create the&nbspLondon Food Alliance.In a bid to make sure&nbspfood gets out to those who need it&nbspas efficiently as possible, the London Food Alliance is now co-ordinating with all 32 London boroughs to make sure the new, council-run community hubs are well-stocked with supplies.Liz Taylor, 61, signed up for volunteering work at The Felix Project last week, and is now packing and delivering food at&nbspthe charity’s main Park&nbspRoyale&nbspwarehouse.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by email“I&nbspthink they’re doing fantastic work here,” says&nbspMs Taylor. “So many people need help at the moment, so it’s been good to be out doing something useful.”Ms Taylor thought it was the right time to lend a helping hand to her 64-year-old husband Graham – who has been volunteering as a delivery driver one day a week since retiring as a consultant last year.“I’ve never liked to see waste, so it made complete sense to me to try and get excess food out to people who need it,” he says. “There’s a great team ethos, maybe because it’s easy to see the benefit of what this project is doing.”When can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?Listen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastBen Salama, a 65-year-old retiree, has been making deliveries for The Felix Project for the past three years, but is now doing extra days to help with push to collect and deliver several tonnes of food to the local authority-run community hubs.“It’s a bit more tiring now, doing deliveries on your own rather than with someone else,” he says. “But I’ve still happy because it feels more important now than ever. It’s actually a bit of relief to get outside and do something. It’s obviously worthwhile, but it’s good for my wellbeing too.”Mohamed Elmi, 34, volunteering with City Harvest for the past 18 months, says&nbspsome of the Acton-based charity’s few dozen or so new volunteers have recently lost jobs in the hospitality industry.“It’s been a difficult time for them but this gives them a sense of purpose,”&nbspsays Mr Elmi, who also works full-time for a homeless healthcare charity. “It’s really helped us fill in for some of the volunteers who are having to stay at home. Yes, we’re putting ourselves at risk – but this work is really needed right now.”London mayor Sadiq Khan told The Independent: “The altruism of the British people in recent days has been a beacon of hope amid the darkness of the coronavirus.”He added: “You can donate spare food at a series of hubs being set up across the city. If you can afford to, you can donate money directly to help keep the food banks open. And if you are fit and healthy, you can volunteer your much-needed time.”The Independent is asking food aid charities across the UK to contact us at helpthehungry@ to tell us about your project and what problems you are facing right now.You can help us build a directory of ways that our readers can help the hungry in their area – through money, volunteering and food donations. title: help the hungry coronavirus food bank felix project covid 19
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The Independent is calling for support to get food to the most vulnerable during the coronavirus crisis – and you can helpToday The Independent launches an appeal to help those going hungry because of the coronavirus crisis.From parents struggling to feed their families after losing their jobs to the vulnerable who have been told to stay inside for the good of their health, thousands across the country now need our help – while many who already used food banks are relying on them more than ever.Across Britain, community hubs are being set up in response to the outbreak to deliver food to many of these people, beginning as early as next week. We have teamed up with The Felix Project – a start-up charity we helped launch in 2016 – to deliver produce to community hubs in London boroughs.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe Independent is also asking food charities across Britain to contact helpthehungry@ to tell us about your project and help build a directory of ways that our readers can help the hungry in their area – through money, volunteering and food donations. Food banks, which were already struggling to meet the need for emergency food parcels, have seen a huge surge in demand in recent weeks, while at the same time coping with dwindling donations, supermarket rationing systems, and a loss of many volunteers to self-isolation – yet none of the government’s rescue money goes to them.British households have stored more than £1bn worth of goods in their homes in response to the pandemic, creating shortages for food banks as shoppers ignore assurances that supply chains are robust.How to support our campaignJess Phillips, the Labour MP who recently ran for party leader, has backed our campaign, saying: “Nobody should be in the position of not being able to get enough food. In my constituency, London and in places all around the UK the coronavirus pandemic is placing extra stress on a system that was already straining.“We should all do what we can to help food and other essentials get to those that need it. That is why I’m backing the Help the Hungry campaign – please give if you are able.”Pastor Obi Onyeabor, the manager at Barking Foodbank, part of The Trussell Trust’s national network, said his pool of around 50 volunteers has been reduced by a dozen or so people currently self-isolating at home. Yet he and his team have kept their two church hall food banks open, and are now making home deliveries on Tuesdays and Thursdays to make sure the most vulnerable get supplies.“We have been scrambling for the past couple of weeks, doing all that we can – but we’re appealing for more people to come and help,” he said. “Out of fear people have been buying for themselves and their families, but I’ve seen some real generosity too.“I hope that if we can get past the panic buying stage, more people will want to give money, food or some of their time too.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailIn London, charities like The Felix Project donate 10 tons of food – or 22,000 meals – to the needy every day. But funding has dropped since the outbreak of Covid-19, limiting their capacity to carry out vital work at a time when it is more important than ever. As part of the London Food Alliance, along with FareShare and City Harvest, The Felix Project will coordinate deliveries in London boroughs in order to distribute surplus food to the elderly, poor and vulnerable. The charities will deliver food to the hubs, where local volunteers will package up parcels and arrange “last-mile” deliveries to the homes of the vulnerable.Sadiq Khan, the mayor of London, has backed our campaign to help in the capital in partnership with our sister title the Evening Standard. He said: “In a city as prosperous as London, everyone should have enough food to feed themselves and their families – but unfortunately the coronavirus outbreak means some Londoners are facing even greater difficulties. It’s commendable these organisations are joining forces to help ensure surplus food isn’t wasted and instead reaches those who need it most. I urge Londoners to support this crucial initiative.”Mark Curtin, CEO of The Felix Project, said: “Our role is to pick up large volumes of nutritious surplus food from the commercial sector and deliver it to community hubs to ensure there is enough food for vulnerable people for as long as this health crisis ensues. We will be working all hours doing our bit – and it would be wonderful if your readers can get behind us so we can do this job for London.”Emma Revie, chief executive of The Trussell Trust, which supports 1,200 food banks, appealed for help from the public to get vital food to people who cannot afford the basics, and to boost volunteer numbers in areas where they are needed.“Our main priority as coronavirus unfolds is ensuring the safety of everyone who comes to a food bank – whether it’s someone needing help, someone volunteering their time, or someone making a donation,” said Ms Revie. “Until we are confident that adequate government protection against poverty is in place, food banks provide an essential community service to people unable to afford food. But this should not fall to food banks.“Our benefits system could be the life raft people need now. That’s why it’s more important than ever that we end the five-week wait for universal credit. While incredible food bank volunteers continue to help people unable to afford the basics, we would ask our government to take this essential step and end the five-week wait now. It’s five weeks too long.”Sabine Goodwin, coordinator of the Independent Food Aid Network UK, which oversees 834 independent food banks, said the charitable services were “struggling to stay above water” in the current climate and accused the government of so far “failing to act” to prevent an ever-increasing number of people falling into poverty.“Food bank use was rising before the coronavirus outbreak and the impact of job losses can only make matters far worse. But this catastrophe in the making is avoidable,” she said. “We’re calling for an income-based solution to this crisis which would mean that the Herculean efforts by volunteers across the country wouldn’t be needed.“FareShare, the UK’s biggest food redistribution charity, is also calling for more volunteers to help with packing and making van deliveries. The organisation takes food from the food manufacturers that can’t be sold in shops, either because of packaging errors or overproduction, and gets it out to food banks, hospices, homeless hostels and other charities.Commercial director Alyson Walsh estimates around 1,200 people have got in touch over the past week. “We have quite a lot of older volunteers who have had to stay at home, but we are now seeing a wave of interest in new people willing to fill in.”Ms Walsh added: “We know we have the capacity to do more – we have the warehouse&nbspspace and the chillers. But the government needs to help the food industry do more in terms of all the bagging and boxing and delivery of food that needs to be done.”Help the hungry&nbsp|&nbspShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - party’s new leader in&nbspa landslide victory after a&nbspthree-month contest to replace Jeremy Corbyn.Sir Keir, who today becomes Labour’s 19th leader in its 120-year history, defeated the left-wing candidate Rebecca Long-Bailey, the shadow business secretary, and the Wigan MP Lisa&nbspNandy for the top job.Securing a convincing majority across all sections of Labour’s electorate – including registered supporters, members and affiliates – and a 56.2 per cent of the vote share overall, he said it was the “honour and privilege of my life” to be elected as the party’s leader.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“I will lead this great party into a new era,” he insisted. “With confidence and hope, so that when the time comes, we can serve our country again – in government.”Shadow education secretary Angela Rayner was also announced as the party’s new deputy leader –&nbspseeing off competition from Richard Burgon, Dawn Butler, Rosena Allin-Khan and Ian Murray – with 52.6 per cent of the vote share.Who will be in Starmer’s shadow cabinet?Keir Starmer’s first 100 days: how can he make a mark in a crisis?New Labour leader Keir Starmer faces challenge of uniting partyStarmer named as new Labour leader in first round of votingWe urgently need an effective opposition – Starmer needs to build oneIt comes as the veteran left-winger Mr Corbyn announced he was stepping aside from the role – after a four and a half years – in the wake of the party’s worst result in terms of parliamentary seats at a general election since 1935.Sir Keir, who served as&nbspshadow Brexit secretary under Corbyn,&nbsphas led the race from the start, winning the backing of 89 members of the parliamentary party in the first round of the contest, before securing the support of more than a dozen affiliated organisations in the second stage.Ballot papers were sent out in late February to the party’s half&nbspa million members, affiliated trade unions and 14,700 “registered supporters” who each paid £25 to take part on a one-off basis.Labour announced the results of the contest online at 10.45am after the party was forced to cancel a planned special members’ conference in central London due to the coronavirus pandemic. Candidates had effectively suspended their campaigns last month as the infections of Covid-19 started to escalate in the UK.Coinciding with Mr Corbyn’s resignation, Boris Johnson also wrote to the leaders of opposition parties at Westminster, inviting them to a briefing of senior government advisers next week as he insisted “we have a duty to work together at this moment of the national unity”.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists.
